2.content:
Protect the seedlings from direct sunlight and heavy rain by creating temporary shade using indigenous materials such as plastic, cogon grass, reeds, or coconut leaves. Construct the shade with a height of 12 centimeters on the east side and 60 centimeters on the west side.

Water the seedlings in the morning to prevent damping-off. Ensure proper watering to keep the soil moist but not overly saturated, as excessive watering can cause damping-off and weak seedlings.

Apply one teaspoon of urea (45-0-0) dissolved in one gallon of water 10 days after germination. Immediately water the seedlings after fertilization to prevent leaf damage.

One week before transplanting, strengthen the seedlings by gradually exposing them to sunlight and adjusting watering.

3.content:
1. Using Plastic Mulch: Create a planting bed that is 1 meter wide and 20 centimeters high.

2. Conventional Method: During the dry season, make furrows.

During the rainy season, form ridges with 1-meter spacing between them.

4.content:
During the rainy season, use one-month-old seedlings as they are sturdier, taller, and can withstand heavy rain.

Plant spacing:
- Dry season: 50 cm apart
- Rainy season: 75 cm apart

For the dry season, transplant 25-day-old seedlings immediately after watering the furrows.

5.content:
To prevent stem damage, hold the seedling by the roots using your thumb and forefinger. Plant it 3 to 5 cm deep, depending on the stem length.

If using seedling trays, transplant the seedling along with the soil from the tray hole.

Transplant in the afternoon or on cloudy days to reduce stress on the seedlings.

Cover newly transplanted seedlings with banana leaves or any available shading materials to protect them.

6.content: Install a trellis for the plants 15 days after transplanting using available materials. This provides support, promotes better air circulation, and prevents fruit rot.

7.content:
Loosen the soil between the plant rows through off-barring 14-21 days after transplanting.

Hill-up the soil 28-35 days after transplanting to provide better root support and promote healthy plant growth.

8.content:
Water the plants as needed. Irrigate the field four to five times from transplanting until 14 days before the final harvest, depending on the soil type.

Tomatoes are highly sensitive to flooding, so watering should be done only to moisten the soil and roots, especially from the flowering stage to harvest. Quickly irrigate the furrows to prevent soil erosion and promote better fruit development.

9.content: Pruning is done to promote healthy plant growth, ensure uniform fruit size, and speed up the harvesting process. It is performed 10–20 days after transplanting or when the branches have grown large. Remove excess branches in the morning to allow the plant wounds to heal faster.

1.content:
>Prepare the planting area early to allow weeds and straw to decompose.
 >Plow and harrow the field two to three times alternately, with a one-week interval. 
 >Plow the soil to a depth of 15-20 cm. 
 >Harrow the field twice to break large clumps of soil and level the planting area. 
 >Finely tilled soil improves aeration and promotes better root growth.

2.content:
A one-hectare farm requires 100 grams of seeds. One gram contains approximately 250 seeds.

There are two methods of raising eggplant seedlings: Seedbed Method and Seedling Tray Method.

Protect the seedlings from excessive sunlight and rain using temporary shading materials such as plastic, cogon grass, talahib, or coconut leaves.

Create a shading structure that is 120 cm high on the east side and 60 cm high on the west side.

Water the seedlings in the morning to prevent damping-off disease. The amount of water should be enough to keep the soil moist but not too wet.

Overwatering weakens the seedlings and increases the risk of damping-off.

On the 10th day after germination, fertilize the seedlings with 1 teaspoon of urea (45-0-0) or ammonium sulfate (21-0-0) dissolved in 4 liters of water.

After fertilization, water the seedbed to prevent leaf damage.

One week before transplanting, harden the seedlings by gradually exposing them to sunlight and reducing watering.

On the first day, expose the seedlings to sunlight until 10:00 AM, then gradually increase exposure time daily until they can withstand full-day sunlight.

3.content:
1. Using Plastic Mulch: Create a planting bed that is 1 meter wide and 20 centimeters high. Leave a 0.5-meter spacing between beds for proper irrigation.

2. Conventional Method: During the dry season, make furrows.

During the rainy season, form ridges that are 1 meter high.

4.content:
Seedlings are ready for transplanting within 4 to 6 weeks after sowing.

Gently uproot the seedlings without removing the soil attached to the roots to ensure survival.

For the conventional method:
- Create furrows with 100 cm spacing per row.
- Most farmers prefer double-row planting to protect fruits from sun scalding.
- Double rows should have 50 cm spacing at the ends and 150 cm spacing between double rows.

For plastic mulch planting:
- Remove soil and transplant seedlings directly into the holes of the plastic sheets.

Transplant 30 to 35-day-old seedlings with 3 to 4 leaves, planting one seedling per hole.

Transplant in cloudy weather or late afternoon to avoid transplanting shock.

Replant within 3 to 5 days if some seedlings do not survive.

Immediately water the newly transplanted seedlings.

5.content:
To prevent stem damage, hold the seedling by the roots using your thumb and forefinger. Plant it 3 to 5 cm deep, depending on the stem length.

If using seedling trays, transplant the seedling along with the soil from the tray hole.

Transplant in the afternoon or on cloudy days to reduce stress on the seedlings.

Cover newly transplanted seedlings with banana leaves or any available shading materials to protect them.

6.content: Install a trellis for the plants 15 days after transplanting using available materials. This provides support, promotes better air circulation, and prevents fruit rot.

7.content:
Loosen the soil between the plant rows through off-barring 14-21 days after transplanting.

Hill-up the soil 28-35 days after transplanting to provide better root support and promote healthy plant growth.

8.content:
Using Plastic Mulch

Irrigate the planting area two days before transplanting to cool the soil under the plastic mulch and dissolve the applied fertilizers.

Conventional Method

Water the furrows to dissolve the applied fertilizer and reduce direct root contact with the fertilizer.

During the dry season:
- Irrigate at 7, 21, and 30 days after transplanting.
- Afterward, water every 10 days.

Eggplants grown with mulch require less water.

During the rainy season, irrigate only when necessary.

Always water after fertilization.

1.content:
Plow and harrow the field two to three times at one-week intervals to prevent weed growth.

After the final leveling, create furrows depending on the season. During the rainy season, the furrow spacing should be three meters. In the dry season, the spacing should be two and a half meters.

Create drainage canals to prevent the plants from falling over during the rainy season.

Zero tillage or no-tillage farming can be applied when planting squash. Before planting, clean the area by manually cutting weeds or applying herbicide.

2.content:
Prepare the following growing media:

One part compost or organic fertilizer
One part clay soil
One part burned rice hull

Fill plastic bags, potlets, or seedbeds with the prepared media.

Water the potting media before planting.

Plant one newly sprouted seed per pot or planting hole.

Place the seedlings in a shaded area.

Water the seedlings regularly as needed.

Harden the seedlings by gradually reducing water and exposing them to direct sunlight.

Transplant the seedlings with a spacing of one meter per hill, 15 days after sprouting or when the true leaves are fully developed.

Transplant in the afternoon or during cloudy weather.

Replant immediately in spots where plants did not survive.

3.content: Remove weeds around the plants 7-14 days after germination. Repeat weeding as needed.

4.content:
The type and amount of fertilizer needed by a plant depend on the results of a soil analysis. If soil testing is not done, follow these recommendations:
• In lowland areas, apply decomposed animal manure or compost fertilizer during plowing, before planting. In highland areas, apply 100 grams of organic fertilizer mixed with one tablespoon of complete fertilizer in each hole before planting.

WATERING
Water plays a crucial role in plant growth, especially for squash during the fruiting stage.
• Side Dressing - Apply one teaspoon of urea to each hill one month after planting or when the plant has one-meter-long vines.
• Two weeks after side-dressing, apply 10 grams of potash (0-0-60) and 60 grams of solophos (0-18-0) to each plant.
• Additional urea or potash may be applied 15 days later depending on the plant's condition.

5.content:
Water plays a crucial role in plant growth, especially for squash during the fruiting stage.

Furrow irrigation is used for large-scale planting. For backyard squash growers, using a sprinkler or any modified irrigation system is recommended.

Irrigate once a week or water each hill with one liter of water per day. Perform irrigation after fertilization.

Stop watering when the fruit reaches the mature green stage, as continued irrigation at this stage may result in lower-quality fruits.

6.content: To increase fruit production when insect pollinators are scarce, perform hand pollination by covering or inserting the male flower, which is the same age as the female flower, between 6:00 and 8:00 in the morning.

7.content:
Harvest young fruits 30-40 days after pollination. Cut a piece of the stem or peduncle using a knife if the fruit is not yet ready for sale to prevent damage.

If seeds are needed, the fruit should show signs of powdery mildew or a white coating on its surface. A hard rind indicates that the squash fruit is fully matured. At this stage, the seeds are fully developed.

Harvest fully matured squash when the fruit has a brownish-orange color if you only need the seeds. Select fruits without symptoms of viral infection (mosaic, yellowing of leaves). This is necessary to avoid transmitting viruses through seeds for the next planting season.
